awd_titl_txt: PFI-TT: A New Deep Neural Network and Internet of Things-based Screening Framework for Sleep Apnea
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation - Technology Translation (PFI-TT) project is to improve sleep apnea screening precision. More than 22 million Americans are affected by sleep apnea. The current home sleep test systems tend to underestimate sleep apnea severity with a high false negative rate. Eighty percent of patients with moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea are never diagnosed. Because sleep apnea is a serious medical condition and a major public health issue, we urgently need a new sleep apnea screening framework. The proposed framework is one of the first deep learning based sleep apnea screening framework using wearable and IoT sensors. It has commercial potential: it can potentially improve screening accuracy by 40 percent with low cost compared with existing sleep apnea screening devices.  The proposed project also includes a broader participant plan. In order to further enhance inclusion of students from all backgrounds, the PFI-TT project will leverage existing programs with schools and programs at the University of Arizona. Additional workshops and teleconferences will be provided for underrepresented groups, particularly women, Hispanic, African Americans and Native Americans, to mentor and coach students with interests in entrepreneurship. The success of our program can be adapted at other institutions nationally and globally through the Desire2Learn program at the University of Arizona. 

The proposed project provides a new sleep apnea screening framework that can addresses the need of low cost together with the need of high precision sleep apnea screening. The intellectual merit of the new sleep apnea screening framework includes a new integrated sleep monitoring wearable sensor, two deep neural network algorithms, and a smart phone based app to collect sleep data and provide screening results. The sleep monitoring wearable sensor incorporates multiple sensors on a single platform with non-volatile memory and low energy Bluetooth. The new deep learning network models classifies the severity of sleep apnea using seven levels based on the Apnea-hypopnea index (AHI). The new models include bidirectional long-short term memory layers and fully connected layers to explore and extract sensory data together with static features such as users' demographic information, existing chronic diseases, and general wellbeing. A post data processing procedure is developed to translate the probability of sleep apnea at the output of deep neural networks to sleep apnea severity using the maximum probability. A smart phone based app is also developed to execute deep neural network algorithms and display sleep apnea screening results.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Our PFI-TT team is an interdisciplinary collaborative effort between researchers in engineering, public health, and medicine; small business companies, and large industrial company; and a patent application unit Tech Launch Arizona at the University of Arizona. Funded by NSF PFI-TT: A New Deep Neural Network and Internet of Things-based Screening Framework for Sleep Apnea Award Number: 1918797, the proposed research addressed sleep disorder breathing (SDB) which is a major public health burden.  More than 12 million Americans are affected by SDB and the prevalence is increasing. The proposed research investigated SDB screening, diagnostics, and monitoring framework. The proposed efforts target the sleep medicine customers and primary care providers. For example, potential customers in sleep medicine include directors of sleep medicine clinics/sleep medical centers, the heads of purchase departments of hospitals, the program directors of sleep research centers, and owners of private sleep medicine clinics. These customers are in need of low cost, high precision and time effective SDB diagnostic solutions. 
The goal of the accomplished efforts is to contribute to sleep medicine community, wearable sensor industrial companies, and educations and training in the related applications. The objectives achieved include: 1) The proposed framework can save up to 80% time spent on data analysis by sleep clinic technicians. 2) The proposed ideas has potential to improve diagnostic precision of SDB by 20%. 3) The proposed research can also provide convenient screening and continuous sleep monitoring at home. 4) With long battery life, the proposed sleep watch is a medical device which can continuously collect high precision data and provide it to sleep professionals continuously or on demand. 
Outcomes in the innovations and trainings: The current home sleep test (HST) on the market employs wearable sensors to collect sleep data and then relies on sleep technicians/specialists to manually read the recorded sleep data and provide scores to health providers. The sleep score indicates whether or not a patient may have a sleep disorder. Noise in wearable sensors, user errors in connecting these sensors, and score inaccuracies due to the large volume of data (8 hours of data with tens of Gbytes) lead to a high false negative rate. Today, one out of three sleep disorder patients in the US are not diagnosed due to the high false negative rate. In addition, sleep test scoring requires years of sleep medicine experience and thus is expensive. False negative rate and high cost are the two major factors that prevent patients from further treatments. In this project, we propose a new machine learning and Internet-of-Things (IoT) based sleep-disorder breathing (SDB) screen, diagnosis, and monitoring framework. The innovations achieved in this award decreases the high false negative rate.  In addition, this team has 1) provided an insight of potential advanced sleep watch which provides high precision sensor data; 2) created a personalized web platform which improves interactions among patients/users and caregivers; and 3) developed a new machine learning and cloud based deep sleep analysis algorithm, which automatically recognizes SDB events from Polysomnography (PSG) records. The developed neural network classifier and achieved close to 95% sensitivity and over 90% specificity for moderate and severe sleep-disordered breathing with thousands of collected subjects stored in the database. Note that this research does not involve human subjects but used existing databases. The developed framework collected biological information such as electrocardiography (ECG), oxygen saturation, motion, etc. The deep sleep analysis algorithm is driven by neural network models. The models can recognize temporal behavior among data and thus improve recognition accuracy. A personalized web platform with auto-adaptive questionnaires can provide additional population information to doctors and aid in the enhancement of analysis algorithms, and thus simplify the sensor selection, data storage, and inference process. This proposed AI-driven framework layed the critical foundation in understanding sleep physiology to produce potentially strategic and practical changes within the population, and ultimately, achieve the transformative social and commercial impact of health assessment and interventions. 
The team has worked with Apple and Esatto Healthcare. Apple can provide us platforms in both hardware and software to help the interface of our framework with their existing customers. Esatto, on the other hand, focuses on medical applications of tools and systems and will be the company licensing our technology.  The team has developed training materials and courses in leadership development in Innovation and Entrepreneurship and have delivered presentations to native American tribes and local Hispanic Communities. 


Last Modified: 06/13/2022
Modified by: Janet M Roveda
